body: Would someone like to have a go at this?  I don't think it is very complicated?

> I want to do it.

Great. 

What needs to happen is this bit of code

https://github.com/ncw/rclone/blob/f0e439de0df77b6ceee197d62f51b47455fe8a3a/fs/config/config.go#L278-L285

Needs to run when the config file is not found

https://github.com/ncw/rclone/blob/f0e439de0df77b6ceee197d62f51b47455fe8a3a/fs/config/config.go#L216-L222

then I think it should all work as `configKey` will be set when we come to save the config.

Perhaps all the loading the key from the environment should be moved up in the file a bit.

Any help doing these much appreciated.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
1. I checked similar issues #3127 and #317 but this request seems to be a little different.
  2. This issue was talked on https://forum.rclone.org/t/possible-to-set-a-password-for-the-rclone-config-file-without-using-rclone-config/10216
#### What is your current rclone version (output from `rclone version`)?
rclone v1.47.0
#### What problem are you are trying to solve?
I help other people create tasks via scripts but would also like the configuration encryption done without going through the interactive menu.  
#### How do you think rclone should be changed to solve that?
To encrypt:
rclone config encrypt "mypassword" or without the "mypassword" and directly retrieve RCLONE_CONFIG_PASS.
To decrypt:
rclone config encrypt ""
and then complete the rclone task with --ask-password=false and setting RCLONE_CONFIG_PASS

Thanks,

Michael Liu

issue.title: Config file encrypted by itself

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?
I'm installing rclone into a container with vagrant. 
- Fresh installation of Debian Stretch with Vagrant
- Run rclone install script: `curl https://rclone.org/install.sh | sudo bash`
- Create mount and config directory: `sudo mkdir -p /etc/rclone & /mnt/remote`
- Copy unencrypted rclone config to /etc/rclone: `sudo cp ~/rclone.conf /etc/rclone`
- Copy systemd service: `sudo cp ~/mount.service /etc/systemd/system/`
- Enable and stard the service
-> rclone config file gets encrypted

Although the file is unencrypted, i have the following entry in my service file: Environment="RCLONE_CONFIG_PASS=pass" (the file was encrypted in the past). If i delete this line from the service file, reinstall the vm, push my service and config file onto the machine again and start the service, it won't get encrypted. It stays unencrypted.

So somehow rclone encrypts my configuration file, when the environment variable RCLONE_CONFIG_PASS in the service file is set.

#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)
rclone v1.48.0
rclone v1.48.0-067-g0a1169e6-beta
(both tested)

#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)
Debian Stretch 64 bit (inside Vagrant)


####  Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)
Google Drive


#### The command you were trying to run (eg `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
ExecStart=/usr/bin/rclone -vvvvvvvv mount \
        --allow-other \
        --config=/etc/rclone/rclone.conf \
        --log-file=/home/vagrant/rclone.log \
        team: /mnt/remote

#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (eg output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
2019/07/16 14:02:33 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.48.0" starting with parameters ["/usr/bin/rclone" "-vvvvvvvv" "mount" "--allow-other" "--config=/etc/rclone/rclone.conf" "--log-file=/home/vagrant/rclone.log" "team:" "/mnt/remote"]  
2019/07/16 14:02:33 DEBUG : Using RCLONE_CONFIG_PASS password.
2019/07/16 14:02:33 DEBUG : Using config file from "/etc/rclone/rclone.conf"
2019/07/16 14:02:33 DEBUG : Encrypted drive 'team:': Mounting on "/mnt/remote"
2019/07/16 14:02:33 DEBUG : drive_team: Loaded invalid token from config file - ignoring
2019/07/16 14:02:34 DEBUG : Keeping previous permissions for config file: -rw-r--r--
2019/07/16 14:02:34 DEBUG : drive_team: Saved new token in config file
2019/07/16 14:02:34 DEBUG : Adding path "vfs/forget" to remote control registry
2019/07/16 14:02:34 DEBUG : Adding path "vfs/refresh" to remote control registry
2019/07/16 14:02:34 DEBUG : Adding path "vfs/poll-interval" to remote control registry
2019/07/16 14:02:34 DEBUG : : Root:
2019/07/16 14:02:34 DEBUG : : >Root: node=/, err=<nil>
2019/07/16 14:03:34 DEBUG : Google drive root '': Checking for changes on remote

issue.title: --config-command="..." or --config-key-command="..." option

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Version: rclone v1.59.1

#### What problem are you are trying to solve?

It would be nice to have a `--config-command` as analogues to the `--password-command` so we can source our own encryption calls for the config file, or provide our own master encryption key (**not** password) to supplement in:

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/f0e439de0df77b6ceee197d62f51b47455fe8a3a/fs/config/config.go#L80

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/f0e439de0df77b6ceee197d62f51b47455fe8a3a/fs/config/config.go#L275

This is particularly useful when we have devices which have their own hardware-backed keystore, such as smartphones. I am [currently](https://github.com/termux/termux-api/issues/550) implementing in Termux the ability to encrypt and decrypt using AES in Android's keystore. The problem with the current method is that I would still need to include the encrypted master password somewhere (such as in a file or sharedpreferences), but it would be preferable if I could source the master key directly from the keystore, or call a command to provide the decrypted config, therefore making sure the password isn't stored anywhere feasibly accessible on the device (even in encrypted form), nor in memory/cache.

Android's keystore supports biometric and pattern authentication and can be unlocked for a certain duration, only when the device is unlocked, for x times, et cetera, so the security of the config file would be greater and never expose the key (encrypted or unencrypted) outside the call.

It would be something like [connection strings](https://rclone.org/docs/#connection-strings), having no persistent configuration data, but maintaining the convenience of not having to manually input the configuration details and not having the command show up in logs, buffer history, et cetera
